case_name: Dr. Shamlal Narula v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 503 of 1963 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 503 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated January 31, 1962, of the Punjab High Court in I.T.R. No. 28 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated January 31, 1962, of the Punjab High Court in I.T.R. No. 28 of 1960.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 9, 1964 by SUBBA RAO, J.

anchor.surface_text: April 9, 1964. The judgment of the Court was delivered by SUBBA RAO, J.-This appeal by certificate

facts.text: Appellant Dr. Shamlal Narula is Manager of a Hindu undivided family.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, Dr. Shamlal Narula, is the Manager of a Hindu undivided family, which owned, inter alia, 40 bighas

facts.text: Hindu undivided family owned 40 bighas and 11 biswas of land in Patiala.

anchor.surface_text: family, which owned, inter alia, 40 bighas and 11 biswas of land in the town of Patiala. The Patiala State

facts.text: Patiala State Government initiated land acquisition proceedings for the land under prevailing Regulation in pari materia with Land Acquisition Act, 1894.

anchor.surface_text: The Patiala State Government initiated land acquisition proceedings for acquiring the said land under Regulation then prevailing in the Patiala State. It is companymon case

facts.text: Relevant facts not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: raises the question whether interest paid under s. 34 of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894, herein- after called the Act, is of the nature of a capital receipt or of a revenue receipt. The relevant facts are number in dispute

facts.text: Patiala State first merged into Union of Pepsu, later Pepsu merged into State of Punjab.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon case that the State Regulations are in pari materia with the provisions of the Act. The State of Patiala first merged into the Union of Pepsu and later the Union of Pepsu merged into the State of Punjab.

facts.text: Land Acquisition Act extended to Union of Pepsu on October 6, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: It is also companymon case that there was a Land Acquisition Act in the Union of Pepsu companytaining provisions similar to those obtaining in the Act. On October 6, 1953, the Act was extended to the Union of Pepsu.

facts.text: Collector of Patiala made award under the Act on September 30, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: On September 30, 1955, the Collector of Patiala made an award under the Act ,as a result of which the appellant received

facts.text: Appellant received Rs. 2,81,822/- on December 1, 1955, including Rs. 48,660/- as interest up to date of award.

anchor.surface_text: On September 30, 1955, the Collector of Patiala made an award under the Act ,as a result of which the appellant received on December 1, 1955, a sum of Rs. 2,81,822/-, which included a sum of 48,660/- as interest up to the date of the award.

facts.text: For assessment year 1956-57, Income-tax Officer included the interest in income of Hindu undivided family and assessed to tax, overruling appellant's contention that it was capital receipt.

anchor.surface_text: For the year 1956-57, the Income-tax Officer included the said interest in the income of the Hindu undivided family of which the appellant is the manager, and assessed the same to income-tax, after overruling the appellants companytention that the said interest was a capital receipt

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed ITO order on June 14, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: On June 14, 1957, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner companyfirmed the order of the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal held interest is capital receipt and excluded it on July 9, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellant preferred an appeal to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal. The said Tribunal by its order dated July 9, 1957, held that the said amount representing the interest was a capital re- ceipt and on that finding the said amount was excluded from the total income of the assessee.

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax referred question to Punjab High Court under s.66(1) Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the Commissioner of Income-tax the said Tribunal referred the following question to the High Court of Punjab under s. 66-  1  of the Income-tax Act, 1922

facts.text: Referred question: Whether Rs.48,660/- under s.34 Land Acquisition Act and award of 30th September 1955 is capital receipt not liable to tax.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on a true interpretation of section 34 of the Land Acquisition Act and the Award given by the Collector of Pepsu on the 30th September, 1955, the sum of Rs. 48,660/-, was captital receipt number liable to tax under the Indian Income tax Act?

facts.text: Punjab High Court Division Bench held amount is revenue receipt liable to tax.

anchor.surface_text: The said reference was heard by a Division Bench of the High Court and it held that the said amount was number a capital but a revenue receipt and as such liable to tax under the Indian Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Appellant contended Rs.48,660/- is compensation for deprivation of right to possession, hence capital receipt.

anchor.surface_text: Learned companynsel for the appellant raised before us two companytentions, namely,  i  the sum of Rs. 4.8,660/- received by the appellant under the award was companypensation for deprivinl,7 him of his right to possession of his property

facts.text: Revenue supported High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the Revenue the order of the High Court is sought to be sustained for the reasons stated therein.

facts.text: Interest under s.34 Land Acquisition Act paid at 6% per annum from taking possession until payment or deposit.

anchor.surface_text: It reads When the amount of such companypensation is number paid or deposited on or before taking possession of the land, the Collector shall pay the amount awarded with interest thereon at the rate of six per centum per annum from the time of so takin- possession until it should have been so paid or deposited.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the Revenue the order of the High Court is sought to be sustained for the reasons stated therein.

arguments.court_reasoning: Court agrees interest under s.34 is revenue receipt for use of withheld money

arguments.claim: s.34 distinguishes between amount awarded as compensation and interest payable thereon from taking possession until payment

anchor.surface_text: The question raised turns upon the true meaning of the provisions of s. 34 of the Act. It reads When the amount of such compensation is not paid or deposited on or before taking possession of the land, the Collector shall pay the amount awarded with interest thereon at the rate of six per centum per annum from the time of so taking possession until it should have been so paid or deposited.

arguments.claim: Interest under s.34 is consideration for use of money or forbearance from demanding it after due, not part of compensation

anchor.surface_text: Section 15 of the Act says that in determining the amount of compensation the Collector shall be guided by the provisions contained in ss. 23 and 24. ... interest pertains to the domain of payment after the compensation has been ascertained. It is a consideration paid either for the use of the money or forbearance from demanding it after it has fallen due.

arguments.claim: After taking possession under s.16 or s.17, land vests absolutely in government; claimant entitled only to compensation plus interest for delay

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 16 of the Act when the Collector has made an award under s. 11 he may take possession of the land which shall thereupon vest absolutely in the Government free from all encumbrances. Under s. 17 thereof In cases of urgency... Such land shall thereupon vest absolutely in the Government, free from all encumbrances.

arguments.claim: Interest under s.34 is paid for use of money by the State after possession taken and title divested

anchor.surface_text: As the land acquired vests absolutely in the Government only after the Collector has taken possession of it, no interest therein will be outstanding in the claimant after the taking of such possession he is divested of his title to the land and his right to possession thereof... Therefore, a statutory liability has been imposed upon the Collector to pay interest... This amount is not, therefore, compensation for the land acquired or for depriving the claimant of his right to possession, but is that paid to the claimant for the use of his money by the State.

arguments.claim: Interest by its nature is compensation for deprivation of use of money, taxable as income (per Westminster Bank)

anchor.surface_text: There is an illuminating exposition of the expression interest by the House of Lords in Westminster Bank, Ltd. v. Riches... interest was a compensation, whether the compensation was liquidated under an agreement or statute... The essential quality of the claim for compensation is the same, and the compensation is properly described as interest.

arguments.claim: Behari Lal case wrongly holds interest u/s.28 is capital as compensation for possession loss since title vests on possession

anchor.surface_text: Where a Tribunal directed the Improvement Trust, under the provisions of s. 28... a Division Bench of the Allahabad High Court held... that the interest so awarded was in the nature of compensation for the loss of the assessees right to retain possession... As we have pointed out earlier, as soon as the Collector has taken possession... the title absolutely vests in the Government...

arguments.claim: Interest u/s.28 same as u/s.34, revenue receipt; Allahabad view rejected by Madras, Patna, Kerala cases also support taxable nature

anchor.surface_text: Adverting to the said decision a Division Bench of the Madras High Court... observed with great respect we find ourselves unable to follow the reasoning... So was the interest granted to an assessee under s. 18A of the Income-tax Act... held to be income taxable... The Madras High Court expressly declined to follow the Allahabad case...

holdings.text: The statutory interest payable under s. 34 of the Land Acquisition Act is not compensation paid to the owner for depriving him of his right to possession of the land acquired, but that given to him for the deprivation of the use of the money representing the compensation for the land acquired.

anchor.surface_text: The scheme of the Act and the express provisions thereof establish that the statutory interest payable under s. 34 is number companypensation paid to the owner for depriving him of his right to possession of the land acquired, but that given to him for the deprivation of the use of the money representing the companypensation for the land acquired.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.34 textually distinguishes compensation from interest; ss.15,23 exclude interest from compensation; interest for use of money post-possession when title vests per ss.16/17.

holdings.text: Interest under s.34 is a revenue receipt liable to tax under the Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: raises the question whether interest paid under s. 34 of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894, hereinafter called the Act, is of the nature of a capital receipt or of a revenue receipt. The relevant facts are number in dispute

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interest is compensation for use of withheld money, akin to profit/loss from money use; affirmed by High Court reasoning and precedents like Westminster Bank.

holdings.text: The sum of Rs. 48,660/- received under s.34 is not compensation for depriving the claimant of right to possession but for use of money by the State.

anchor.surface_text: This amount is number, therefore, companypensation for the land acquired or for deprivin- the claimant of his right to possession, but is that paid to the claimant for the use of his money by the State.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Post-possession, title vests in Government; claimant entitled only to compensation plus interest for delay in payment.

holdings.text: No difference in character of interest under s.34 whether possession taken before or after award; in either case title vests only after possession.

anchor.surface_text: In this view there cannot be any difference in the legal position between a case where possession has been taken before and that where possession has been taken after the award, for in either case the title vests in the Government only after possession has been taken.

holdings.reasoning_summary: ss.16 and 17 both vest title upon taking possession, regardless of award timing.

holdings.text: Interest under s.28 of the Land Acquisition Act, just like under s.34, is not compensation for loss of right to possession but for withholding the compensation amount.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the interest awarded under s. 28 of the Act, just like under s. 34 thereof, cannot be a companypensation or damages for the loss of the right to retain possession but only companypensation payable by the State for keeping back the amount payable to the owner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Same vesting of title on possession; rejects Behari Lal view distinguishing s.28.

holdings.text: Interest under s.18A of the Income-tax Act is income taxable.

anchor.surface_text: So was the interest granted to an assessee under s. 18A of the Income-tax Act on the advance payment of tax by him under the provision of that section held to be income taxable

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory interest on advance tax payments is taxable income, consistent with general principle.

anchor.surface_text: There is an illuminating exposition of the expression interest by the House of Lords in Westminster Batik, Ltd. v. Riches 1 . The question there was whettier where in an action for recovery of any debt or damages the companyrt exercises its discretionary power under a statute and orders that there shall be included in the sum for which the judgment is given interest on the debt or damages, the sum of interest so included is taxable under the Income-tax Acts.

precedents.cited_proposition: statutory interest represents compensation for deprivation of use of money and has the quality of interest
precedents.cited_holding: interest, whether statutory or contractual, represents the profit the creditor might have made if he had the use of the money or the loss he suffered because he had not that use

Commissioner of Income-tax, C. P. and U. P. 1 , that the interest so awarded was in the nature of companypensation for the loss of the assessees right to retain possession of the property acquired and, therefore, was numberincome liable to tax.

anchor.surface_text: The scheme of the Act and the express provisions thereof establish that the statutory interest payable under s. 34 is number companypensation paid to the owner for depriving him of his right to possession of the land acquired, but that given to him for the deprivation of the use of the money representing the companypensation for the land acquired.
